snippet.title: Is this the end for Mitchell?
snippet.content:
SAM Mitchell is expected to make a call on his playing future at a press conference tomorrow morning. Mitchell is tipped to retire from playing at the end of the season to start his full-time assistant coaching duties at West Coast. The 34-year-old was a four-time premiership player with the Hawks before joining the Eagles late last year from Hawthorn in a shock recruiting move. With 323 games under his belt, Mitchell is one of the most decorated players in the game, with a Brownlow Medal (2012), five Hawthorn best-and-fairest awards (2006, 2009, 2011-12, 2016) and three All Australian jumpers (2011, 2013, 2015).
Sam Mitchell retiring tomorrow.
Mitchell has been one of the Eagles' most consistent players, and has averaged 27 disposals this year. Mitchell's expected retirement comes amid mounting pressure on West Coast coach Adam Simpson to turn to youth, with the Eagles sporting the oldest list in the competition. He will be the second Brownlow medallist to retire within a week, with teammate Matt Priddis calling time on his career on Friday. Adam Simpson speaks to 7 News
SAM MITCHELL'S CAREER AT A GLANCE Drafted: 2001 by Hawthorn (pick 36) Age: 34 (fifth-oldest current AFL player) Games: 323 (307 Hawthorn, 16 West Coast) Goals: 69 Disposals: 8529 (fifth all-time) Premierships in 2008, 2013, 2014, 2015 Brownlow Medallist in 2012 Brownlow votes: 220 (equal-most in AFL era) Club champion in 2006, 2009, 2011, 2012, 2016 All-Australian in 2011, 2013, 2015

sindex.name: SAM MITCHELL'S CAREER AT A GLANCE
